image.altText: Veronika Gobba in a dark shirt, holding a pink takeaway coffee cup and a stack of textbooks.

props.synopsis: Drowning in HECS debt amid a housing affordability crisis, students are choosing frozen yoghurts and bubble teas to pep themselves up when saving feels futile.

title.children: 'Why bother saving?': Students opt for 'little treats' amid cost of living pressures

image.altText: A destroyed building with green insulation flying out of the roof area.

props.synopsis: Footage of a powerful tornado that tore through the Western Australian city of Bunbury shows it travelling rapidly as it shreds rooftops and damages homes.

title.children: Footage shows 'frightening' tornado tear off prison roof as city left in chaos

image.altText: Tom Brough

props.synopsis: Albany doctor and local councillor Thomas Brough has been approved for preselection for the Liberal Party, despite making controversial comments about the LGBTQIA+ community.

title.children: WA Liberal party approves Dr Thomas Brough, candidate who linked LGBTQIA+ community with paedophiles

image.altText: Image of hundreds of sheep being held in an open air shed, waiting for export.

props.synopsis: Federal Agriculture Minister Murray Watt says the transition is "orderly and considered", while the Nationals are vowing to reverse the ban if the coalition wins the next election.

title.children: Australian live sheep export trade to end in 2028 as government unveils $107m support package

props.synopsis: After two rounds of semis, 25 countries are facing off in Malmö, Sweden to be crowned the winner of Eurovision 2024. Follow live.

title.children: Eurovision performances finish following Dutch disqualification, grand final countdown begins

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: The top three so far in jury votes
You can vote now, so don't forget!

image.altText: Grief educator Rebecca Feinglos, who has thick brunette hair, poses for a photo in a garden setting wearing a fawn coloured top

props.synopsis: For many of us, Mother's Day is a time when our hearts are a bit sore. I miss my own mother so much. I miss her humour, her levity, her wisdom, and the way she made everything seem better. So how should we think about this day when grief is still fresh?

title.children: If the Hallmark version of Mother's Day feels like a punch in the gut, you're not alone

image.altText: White glowing rectangular and circular pullouts on top of photograph of Archie Moore sitting with his artwork kith and kin.

props.synopsis: It took four people months to draw Archie Moore's enormous family tree – but it'll all be erased soon.

title.children: It took four people months to draw this epic family tree – and it'll all be erased soon

image.altText: Tom Gleeson on the set of Hard Quiz gesturing behind him with a serious expression.

props.synopsis: Still trying to convince people you can beat my quiz? Let's see if you can.

title.children: Always said you'd smash Hard Quiz? I'll believe it when I see it … Let's play, HARD!

image.altText: Four men on a three-wheeled motorbike and a trailer, carrying containers and mattresses.

props.synopsis: An estimated 300,000 Palestinians have now left Rafah, as Israel vows to go ahead with its planned offensive in the face off international pressure.

title.children: Tens of thousands of Palestinians evacuate Rafah as aid agencies warn food is running out

image.altText: A middle aged bald white man standing on a country road in front of a parked motorbike.

props.synopsis: Trying to get an appointment with a psychologist or psychiatrist can be a battle, but for people in regional Australia it can be almost impossible. They say the lack of services is dangerous and are desperate for more support.

title.children: Sam had a history of suicide attempts but couldn't see a psychiatrist for almost a year

image.altText: A woman with a bouffant chats to a blonde woman in a pale blue evening gown

props.synopsis: When Diana was 15, her father secretly married a glamorous, younger woman. The future princess and her stepmother became locked in a bitter rivalry. But it ended with a surprise friendship.

title.children: Diana shoved her 'wicked' stepmother down the steps and ruined her reputation. Here's how they became friends

image.altText: Bank of big fans stacked on top of each other

props.synopsis: Sucking carbon dioxide directly out of the air and burying underground is touted as a crucial way to avoid the worst of global warming. So how does it work, and is it for real?

title.children: In Iceland, a giant vacuum hoovers up carbon. Is it a solution to global warming, or a dangerous distraction?

image.altText: A woman wearing a sari holds up a photo of a man wearing a white shirt and red and yellow scarf.

props.synopsis: A candidate in India’s elections has been mired in scandal after almost 3,000 videos began circulating of him allegedly sexually assaulting multiple women. Here’s how the issue has sparked a national conversation around the treatment of women.

title.children: A politician from an Indian political dynasty was running for election. Then someone found a USB drive with shocking contents

image.altText: Ninette Simons with severe facial bruising some days after the attack.

props.synopsis: Another man charged over the alleged bashing of a Perth woman during a violent home invasion is a former immigration detainee released into the community while the Coalition was in government in 2020.

title.children: Second man charged over Perth bashing revealed to be former detainee released under Coalition's watch

image.altText: A man in a suit leaves an apartment.

props.synopsis: Rishi Sunak has been hit with crippling blows at council elections in the UK but as the country potentially turns to Labor, he is increasingly turning towards a past Australian solution to cling to power.

title.children: Sending asylum seekers to Rwanda may be illegal, it may also save Britain's PM

image.altText: Courtroom sketch of Donald Trump. He is in the centre of the frame with a flash of yellow hair standing out in a purple scene.

props.synopsis: From "surfboard eyebrows" to an "incredible coiffe", veteran courtroom sketch artist Christine Cornell explains how she captures the features and the feelings of Donald Trump's hush money trial.

title.children: Meet the artist behind the viral courtroom sketches of Donald Trump

image.altText: Gayle Dickerson takes a selfie with her son at a cafe table

props.synopsis: We hear from four mothers about the highs of lows of parenting after 40.

title.children: Women share the highs and lows of being a new mum in your 40s

image.altText: Joost Klein, representing The Netherlands, performs onstage during a rehearsal.

props.synopsis: Dutch artist Joost Klein is kicked out of from the Eurovision Song Contest following a complaint made by a female member of the production crew, the European Broadcasting Union says.

title.children: Dutch artist Joost Klein kicked out of Eurovision after complaint from female staffer

image.altText: Police in Kupang, East Nusa Tenggara speak to a group of Chinese and Indonesian men

props.synopsis: Police in Kupang name seven suspected people smugglers after intercepting a boat carrying Chinese and Indonesian people they believe were headed to Australia.

title.children: Indonesian police name suspected people smugglers after intercepting boat headed to Australia

image.altText: Matt Guelfi

props.synopsis: Matt Guelfi sends a message to a young fan as the Bombers score a crucial victory over the Giants, as the Bulldogs, Suns and Hawks enjoy much-needed victories.

title.children: 'We are crying': Bombers forward's beautiful gesture to young fan warms the heart

image.altText: Harry Grant looks surprised as he runs off with the referee crossing his hands behind him

props.synopsis: Cronulla, without the injured Nicho Hynes, ends Melbourne's home run with a dramatic 25-18 victory to remain top of the NRL ladder as Newcastle, St George Illawarra secure wins.

title.children: 'What has happened to rugby league?' Cronulla claims dramatic victory after Harry Grant's controversial sin binning

image.altText: A Wallaroos player holds the ball while being tackled by two Canadian players.

props.synopsis: It wasn't the start to the Pacific Four Series the Wallaroos were hoping to make, but they feel they're heading in the right direction despite the 33-14 scoreline against the Canadians.

title.children: Wallaroos find 'positives' in convincing loss to Canada

image.altText: An athlete in a red shirt kneels low on the ground clutching his head as a man in a suit stands over him.

props.synopsis: World number one Novak Djokovic requires medical attention after being hit by a water bottle following his second-round win against France's Corentin Moutet in Rome.

title.children: 'We're checking video footage': Investigation underway after Djokovic hit by water bottle at Italian Open

image.altText: Giants

props.synopsis: Play was resumed in a Super Netball match almost an hour after the final siren, after a scoreboard mistake incorrectly showed the Lightning had defeated the Giants in regular time.

title.children: Stunning scoreboard mistake in Super Netball sees teams called back almost an hour after the final siren to play extra time

image.altText: A man on a stretcher surrounded by emergency workers. One worker is holding the man's arm in the air.

props.synopsis: Rescuers are still searching for 29 people that remain unaccounted-for.

title.children: Man pulled from the rubble of collapsed building after five days in South Africa, 13 confirmed dead

image.altText: A woman with grey short hair wearing a suit.

props.synopsis: Speaking after Australia backed a resolution expanding the rights afforded to the Palestinian United Nations delegation, Foreign Minister Penny Wong says the government no longer believes recognition of Palestinian statehood can only come at the end of an Israel-Palestine peace process.

title.children: Wong says Australia could recognise Palestinian statehood before peace process is complete

image.altText: A close-up of an old woman crying while being hugged by another woman.

props.synopsis: Thousands of Ukrainian villagers are evacuated as fierce fighting rages into a second day on the fringes of Ukraine's north-eastern Kharkiv region.

title.children: Evacuations as fierce fighting rages in Ukraine's Kharkiv region, Russia touts gains

image.altText: Blue and white police tape borders a tree and white car, with a red brick house with people outside

props.synopsis: A man wanted in connection with a historical murder investigation is arrested 16 years later, after flying into Melbourne from Bangkok.

title.children: Man to be extradited to South Australia in connection with 2007 murder

image.altText: Bruce Lehrmann leaves Federal Court in Sydney, surrounded by people, looking serious

props.synopsis: Federal Court Justice Michael Lee on Friday ordered Bruce Lehrmann to pay costs of a higher order than typically seen in defamation cases, but also declared there were "no real winners" in the multi-million-dollar legal battle.

title.children: What happens if Bruce Lehrmann can't afford to pay the massive legal bill coming his way

image.altText: a scene of a road and grass on two sides with the sky lit up with a wide array of colourful rays.

props.synopsis: The aurora borealis and australis — the northern and southern lights — are captured by photographers around the world as a rare solar weather event colours the skies in magical hues.

title.children: In pictures: Stunning auroras seen around world as geomagnetic storm hits Earth

image.altText: Sky at night lit up in pink hues with trees and a road below.

props.synopsis: The Earth has experienced its strongest geomagnetic storm of the past 20 years, resulting in stunning light displays across the globe. But what are geomagnetic storms exactly and do they present a risk to people or the planet?

title.children: What are geomagnetic storms and why do they produce such stunning light displays?

image.altText: A woman smiles.

props.synopsis: A review finds the emergency department in South Australia's largest public hospital is "not designed or resourced" to deliver effective mental health care.

title.children: Mental health review findings released after woman's alleged stabbing murder

image.altText: Aerial shot of dozens of houses in neat rows in a new outer-suburban housing estate.

props.synopsis: Billions more will be committed to building new homes in next week's federal budget, as the government chases a promise to build 1.2 million by the end of the decade.

title.children: 'Less talk and more homes': Budget to pump billions into housing in pursuit of 1.2 million new homes

image.altText: A tall, balding middle-aged white man in glasses and a suit walks on a seaside footpath with a crowd of people.

props.synopsis: The Princess of Wales stepped away from public duties in March after announcing she had been diagnosed with an undisclosed form of cancer and was undergoing preventative chemotherapy.

title.children: Prince William says Kate is 'doing well', in rare public comment about the princess's condition

image.altText: Donald Trump's former lawyer and fixer Michael Cohen smiles as he arrives for a second day of testimony before a grand jury.

props.synopsis: Michael Cohen was once Trump's personal attorney and said he would "take a bullet" for his boss, so what happened to make him flip?

title.children: Michael Cohen has destroyed his life trying to put Donald Trump in jail. Here's why he flipped on his former boss
